headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; By Telegraph to the New-York Daily Times. Removal of Commissioner Wilson--Department Clerks to be Dismissed--Absence of the President.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. WILSON, Commissioner of the Land Office, has been removed, and Mr. WHITING, Chief Clerk of the Interior Department, has been appointed temporarily in his place. PHILIP CLAYTON's hours are numbered, About thirty Department Clerks will be dismissed on the 1st of July-some for Know-Nothingism, and others for intemperance. Seven have

byline.original: Special Dispatch to the New-York Daily Times

headline.main: LONG ISLAND.; SUICIDE OF TWO LOVERS. Mysterious Affair--Great Excitement in Brooklyn.

docs.lead_paragraph: Brooklyn was thrown into a feverish state of excitement yesterday morning by a rumor which had spread throughtout the city, that a young man and woman had been found dead in each other's arms on a piazza in the rear of the house of a respectable citizen on Clermont-avenue, near Myrtle.

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; HARD SHELL DEMONSTRATION. Mass Meeting at the Metropolitan Theatre. Speeches, Resolutions, Letters, &c. The Liquor Movement.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Theatre was filled last evening in all its parts by the Hard-Shell wing of the Demeracy, agreeably to a call Issued for a Mass Meeting to take into consideration the condition and prospects of the National Demoeracy. At 8 1/4 o'clock JOHN B. HASKIN Esq., called the meeting to order, and nominated Hon, SAMUEL HEARDSLEY as President. The nomination was necepted. The President on takin the Chair said:
docs.abstract: Letter to N. Y. Hard meeting

docs.lead_paragraph: The Newark Advertiser controverts the idea of a French writer, that the west ends of cities are generally more healthy than other points of the municipal compass. It admits, however, that so far as the observation of the Parisian went, that end is peopled by the wealthier and more protentious classes; and in granting this it sacrifices, we think, all the strength of its position. docs.lead_paragraph: The President has appointed GEORGE C. WHITING, Chief Clerk of the Interior Department, acting Commissioner ad interim. Mr. WILSON'S removal was solely for political reasons. The President, with Mrs. PIERCE, left this afternoon for Baltimore. They will proceed from thence privately to the Jersey shore, or country, for the benefit of Mrs. P.'s health, which has been feeble of late.

headline.main: Retaliation or Disunion--Letter from John C. Calhoun.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the Charleston Mercury. The subjoined letter from Mr. CALHOUN, it is stated by one of our exchanges, has been given to the public within the past few days. Anything from his pen will be acceptable to our readers. It is on the subject of retaliation by the South for the wrongs and indignities ??eaped upon her by the Abolition States :
docs.abstract: In favor of Retaliation or Disunion

docs.lead_paragraph: The Sunday Atlas gives the particulars of a Corporation job, which the Common Council would do well to investigate. In December, 1853, the ship Joseph Walker was burned, and her hulk sunk loaded with grain, at the foot of Dover-street, where it still remains. headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; From Washington. By Telegraph to the New-York Daily Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: WILLIAM BURWELL, or Virginia, will supply the place of Mr. ELLIS, as Editor of the American Organ during the temporary absence of Mr. E. on account of ill health. The Collector of New-York has been ordered to give a clearance to the KINNEY steamer; provided the law is complied with.

docs.lead_paragraph: American Institute-Farmers' Club. A stated meeting of the Farmers' Club was held yesterday at noon, at the Repository, No. 351 Boradway. There was a larger attendance than usual.
